newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish central bank sells dlrs for lira-bankers.
newsitem.headline: Turkish central bank sells dlrs for lira-bankers.

text.p: Turkish central bank sold dollars for lira to banks on Monday afternoon to curb demand for the U.S. currency fuelled by excess liquidity, bankers said.
The lira firmed to around 120,800 against the dollar after the central bank intervention from a previous 120,880.
"There was some dollar demand in the afternoon. So the central bank stepped in to restrain the dollar's rise," said a private banker.
The lira opened at 120,900 to the dollar, weaker on Friday's 119,840 close amid caution ahead of parliamentary debates on corruption allegations against Deputy PM Tansu Ciller.
But it firmed to 120,800 at midday after the central bank drained 25.4 trillion lira of a 44.5 trillion lira surplus by a reverse repo auction on the open market in the morning.
Bankers said the lira weakened versus the dollar again in the afternoon due to ongoing political concerns in markets despite rising money rates.
Overnight money rates gradually firmed to 71 percent from 70 at midday before the intervention and rose further to 71.75 after the central bank's dollar sales.
The Turkish parliament will vote on two separate corruption probes against Ciller on Tuesday and Wednesday.
